entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Enabling Scalable Growth for Mid-Sized Companies
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Enabling Scalable Growth for Mid-Sized Companies


In highly competitive market, these days the impact of mid-sized companies is hard to miss; they’ve learned to position themselves in a crowded market. To succeed, they stay quick, dream up fresh ideas, chase growth and yet still juggle limited money, shifting customer demands and rules from many regulation authorities. That is where SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud steps in - a strong, public-cloud answer that scales on command, speeds up innovation, offers enterprise-grade tools and cuts out most of the usual IT headaches.

Scaling Smart: Navigating Growth Challenges in the Mid-Market Sector

Mid-sized companies find themselves compressed between the big companies and the start-ups. Like the big players, they do not enjoy huge IT teams or expensive resources for year-long tech rollouts, yet their day-to-day headaches are just as trapped. Running operations in multiple countries, adjusting several product lines, keeping up with shifting rules, and pushing ahead with digital change all demand solid tools and budget. After all these conflicts, keeping companies balance sheet in shiny condition is not that easy. If they hang on to that aging ERP or a patchwork of outdated apps and systems, the drag can swallow momentum, showing up as:

  • Extra stress in meeting tough compliance standards
  • Focus shift from priorities to non-priorities activities, hurdles that block entry into fresh markets or regions
  • Isolation that keep departments talking past each other
  • On-premises systems that pile up hidden total cost of ownership
  • Rigid procedures with little automation and avoiding changes which will keep away from latest and cost-effective solution.

 What is SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud product is all about?

With pre-configured best practices, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is a scalable, cloud-based ERP solution that optimises business operations. Through the Central Business Configuration tool, it facilitates industry-specific configurations, minimal customisation, and quick deployment.

Continuous innovation, real-time insights, and sustainability tracking are made possible by its integrated AI, machine learning, and tools such as Signavio and SAP Analytics Cloud. Flexibility and compatibility are guaranteed by a smooth integration with both SAP and non-SAP systems.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is a future-ready ERP platform that offers agility, innovation, and sustainability, making it the perfect choice for organisations looking to modernise. Below are the key features of SAP Public cloud,

Now, let’s see how all mentioned features can drive scalable growth for small and mid-sized companies.

 

1. Total cost of owner ship & Cost Effectiveness

Consider infrastructure upgrades, continuous system maintenance, specialised IT support, and those annoying manual updates. Traditional ERP systems can have some unforeseen costs. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, on the other hand, adopts a different strategy with its subscription-based model, allowing you to benefit from predictable operational expenses and a significantly reduced total cost of ownership (TCO).

Here are a few benefits:

  • You avoid the headache of project-based upgrades and receive constant innovations and updates.
  • No requirement for sizable IT staffs or substantial physical infrastructure
  • Backups, disaster recovery, and cybersecurity are all integrated into SAP's secure data centres.

Mid-sized businesses can now more easily access and afford enterprise-grade ERP capabilities thanks to this model. By using SAP public cloud, companies can save around 50% of implementation cost.

 

2. Accelerated ROI through faster deployment and adoption

Businesses can quickly and efficiently implement SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud thanks to the SAP Activate methodology and SAP ALM. Implementation time is greatly reduced, frequently going live in 12 to 16 weeks (For less complex business), thanks to predefined business processes, guided configuration tools, and automated testing.

This type of flexibility enables mid-sized businesses to:

  • Avoid long project cycles
  • Reduce the cost of implementation
  • Reallocate internal resources to strategic business objectives.
  • See a return on investment almost immediately. Additionally, SAP provides pre-configured industry content (such as for professional services, manufacturing, and wholesale distribution), which enables businesses to more quickly align with the demands of their particular sector.

I have seen often small and mid-size industries facing lot of challenges with resources and budget, SAP Public cloud solution can be real game changer for these companies. By using SAP public cloud companies can save around 60% of their time.

3. Public cloud package –

As per my experience, it will be always beneficial to business if they consider SAP cloud ERP as a package. It often includes ALM (Application lifecycle management), BTP (Business technology platform) and other services.

Advantages of the packages,

  • Pay as you go model
  • Cost effective
  • Bundled value
  • Quick time to value
  • Innovation Ready
  • For few products no separate licencing is required

4. Continuous Innovation, Delivered Quarterly

Thanks to automatic quarterly updates, SAP keeps your experience fresh and evolving bringing you new features, smarter tools, and meaningful enhancements like:

  • Keeping pace with changes in national laws and regulations
  • Refining processes and boosting overall performance
  • Enhancing intelligence and user experience through AI and machine learning

In todays competitive market business should focus on their priorities, it will be very dangerous for business to involved in unproductive or less productive area, especially it can be big hurdle for mid-size companies.

With Public cloud business can be competitive and flexible with enjoying access to newest product features available to them without any extra efforts on expansive upgrades and dip pre-launch testing. SAP will take care of all upgrade process on the behalf of companies so there will be very less chance of errors and failures.

5. Flexible, Future-Proof Scalability

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is thoughtfully built to grow with your business — scaling effortlessly in every direction.

  • Companies can improve their systems by adding new functionalities as their needs evolve over a period of time, such as Integrated Order-to-Cash and Procure-to-Pay, Advanced Financial Planning & Analysis or subscription billing and real time data.
  • On other side once business expectation fulfilled they can use the same global template to expand into new business units, regions, or subsidiaries.

Since it’s built for the cloud from the ground up, businesses can easily scale without pouring money into new hardware. That makes it perfect for companies planning to grow internationally or handle mergers and acquisitions. Even mid-sized firms can tap into the public cloud to reach their goals faster and more affordably.

6. Built-in intelligent technology solutions

SAP S/4HANA Intelligent technologies that improve decision-making, simplify daily tasks, and optimise business processes abound in the public cloud:

Even with smaller teams, these features enable mid-sized businesses to function more effectively working smarter, not harder. To be more precise, business can also take advantages of Joule for reporting or taking accurate data from system is fraction of second.

7. Global Compliance with Local Precision

Localisations for more than 40 countries are pre-installed in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and include:

  • Handling all necessary documentation and compliance filings as per local requirements.
  • Meeting country-specific tax and legal obligations, including e-invoicing, GST, and VAT.
  •  Providing financial reporting structures and customized charts of accounts suited to local standards.

With all specific local features business can enter in the market with confidence as SAP has already taken all the headache and incorporated all region-specific issues in advanced in the SAP product, so business can concentrate on other important aspect which is important for business growth.

8. Collaborative Framework for Functional Integration

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud eliminates data silos and produces a unified picture of the company by integrating finance, supply chain, procurement, HR, and sales onto a single platform. Integrated analytics and dashboards provide decision-makers with real-time insights, such as:

  • Analysis of profitability by product, region, or customer
  • Current stock levels in every warehouse
  • Different pre-defined KPIs

Better decision-making, faster reactions, and more strategic growth planning are made possible by this instant visibility.

Summary:  Impact on mid-size businesses

SAP S/4HANA is a game-changer for mid-sized businesses, acting as a powerful catalyst for growth and innovation that goes well beyond just being a cloud-based ERP. The goal of SAP cloud ERP is to transition all mid-sized businesses to the cloud, allowing them to experience significant improvements by leveraging all the features and technologies available for their growth.

In summary, considering all these points, we can confidently say that SAP cloud ERP is a key driver of success. It supports businesses in various ways, including strategy, value, cost management, innovation, and fostering genuine growth.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud isn’t just a tool for businesses aiming to expand without the usual headaches; it’s a true partner in growth. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud, customers can expect to see a 50% reduction in IT staff compared to traditional ERP systems.

entry.title: Uploading ZIP/CSV Files as BLOBs in SAP HANA HDI Containers – The Missing Guide
entry.content:
Use Case:

I had to load a static ZIP file into an HDI container table for downstream processing. These ZIP files contain industry best practices that are consumed by a downstream system to apply standardized configurations. The challenge? Getting those ZIPs into the HDI container in a way that works with .hdbtabledata.

Challenge:

This seemingly simple requirement comes with some surprising limitations:

  • You can't upload ZIPs via SAP HANA Database Explorer directly.
  • You can't use `.hdbtabledata` for raw BLOBs without transformation.
  • HDI containers don’t expose a "file system" where you can drop files for SQL access.

Our Approach

We developed an automated, script-based approach:

  1. A shell script to convert ZIP files into Base64 strings.

  2. A CSV file that holds metadata like ID, NAME, SKU_ID, and the encoded ZIP content.

  3. A .hdbtabledata configuration to decode Base64 into binary and store it in a BLOB column.

Why Convert ZIP to Base64 in This Case?

The .hdbtabledata mechanism used for importing data into HDI containers expects text-based formats like CSV. However:

  • ZIP files are binary and contain null bytes or special characters that break CSV formatting.

  • Base64 encoding transforms binary content into a safe, ASCII string, suitable for CSV and text-based tools.

  • Later, we decode the Base64 string during the HDI import to restore the original ZIP binary into a BLOB column.

Table Definition

CREATE COLUMN TABLE "MY_CONTAINER"."ZIP_STORE" (
    "ID" NVARCHAR(50),
    "NAME" NVARCHAR(255),
    "FILE" BLOB,
    "SKU_ID" NVARCHAR(50)
);

 

Metadata

IDNAMESKU_IDZIP_FILE
b504b47a-50b6-4a16-8e5b-471cc88b6a6aBASE_TEMPLATE_80078838007883ZIP_BP_20250609.zip
99ded8ca-c59f-4103-b933-9049e9568185BEST_PRACTICE_80078858007885ZIP_BP_20250609.zip

Shell Script

#!/bin/bash

# Input: list of entries (ID, logical NAME, SKU_ID, ZIP_FILE)
INPUT_LIST="file_list.csv"

# Output: final CSV for .hdbtabledata
OUTPUT_CSV="BASE_TEMPLATE_DATA.csv"

# Start output CSV with header
echo "ID,NAME,FILE,SKU_ID" > "$OUTPUT_CSV"

# Loop through file list
tail -n +2 "$INPUT_LIST" | while IFS=',' read -r ID NAME SKU_ID ZIP_FILE; do
  ID=$(echo "$ID" | tr -d '\r')
  NAME=$(echo "$NAME" | tr -d '\r')
  SKU_ID=$(echo "$SKU_ID" | tr -d '\r')
  ZIP_FILE=$(echo "$ZIP_FILE" | tr -d '\r')
  # Check file exists
  if [[ ! -f "$ZIP_FILE" ]]; then
      echo "File not found: $ZIP_FILE"
      exit 1
  fi
  # Encode zip file
  BASE64_CONTENT=$(base64 < "$ZIP_FILE" | tr -d '\n')
  echo "$ID,$NAME,\"$BASE64_CONTENT\",$SKU_ID" >> "$OUTPUT_CSV"
done
echo "Final CSV created: $OUTPUT_CSV"

 

Output CSV

IDNAMEFILESKU_ID
b504b47a-50b6-4a16-8e5b-471cc88b6a6aBASE_TEMPLATE_8007883UEsDBBQACAgIAJ1oiFoAAAAAAAAA......8007883
99ded8ca-c59f-4103-b933-9049e9568185BEST_PRACTICE_8007885UEsDBBQACAgIAJ1oiFoAAAAAAAAA......8007885


Final Step

Now that we have the Base64-encoded CSV ready, we need to update .hdbtabledata to decode the FILE column back to binary.

Why This Is Required

We converted ZIPs to Base64, but HANA expects raw binary in the BLOB column. The decodeBase64 function tells the HDI importer to convert Base64 back to binary before inserting into the table.

What This Does

"FILE": {
  "name": "decodeBase64",
  "type": "function",
  "parameters": {
    "column_name": "FILE"
  }
}

In .hdbtabledata, this configuration says:

  • "name": "decodeBase64" – tells SAP to decode the Base64 string.

  • "type": "function" – uses built-in transformation, not static mapping.

  • "column_name": "FILE" – applies decoding only to this column.

 

Final .hdbtabledata File

{
  "format_version": 1,
  "imports": [
    {
      "target_table": "BASE_TEMPLATE",
      "source_data": {
        "data_type": "CSV",
        "file_name": "BASE_TEMPLATE_DATA.csv",
        "has_header": true,
        "type_config": {
          "delimiter": ","
        }
      },
      "import_settings": {
        "import_columns": [
          "ID",
          "NAME",
          "FILE",
          "SKU_ID"
        ],
        "include_filter": []
      },
      "column_mappings": {
        "ID": "ID",
        "NAME": "NAME",
        "FILE": {
          "name": "decodeBase64",
          "type": "function",
          "parameters": {
            "column_name": "FILE"
          }
        },
        "SKU_ID": "SKU_ID"
      }
    }
  ]
}

 

Conclusion

This approach provides a clean and reproducible way to store binary ZIP content inside SAP HANA HDI containers using only CSV and shell scripting — no manual intervention or external file handling required at import time.

By converting binary ZIPs to Base64 and decoding them during the .hdbtabledata import, we work around the limitation of HDI containers not supporting direct file system access or native binary uploads.

This method is especially useful when:

  • You want to automate bulk loading of template ZIPs or configuration files.

  • You’re building dev/test environments and want reproducible data setups.

  • You need to version and transport BLOB content as part of your HDI artifacts.

Hopefully, this saves you the hours I spent figuring it out. If you face additional challenges or optimize this further — feel free to share back!

Happy to answer questions or collaborate if you’re doing something similar.

entry.title: Session 5 Recap & Highlights - Planning Your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Let's review the key insights from our session on 'Planning your transition path to SAP Business Data Cloud'.

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) marks a transformative approach to enterprise data management and utilization. This comprehensive SaaS platform centralizes and governs SAP data assets while integrating effortlessly with external data sources. BDC is designed to tackle the increasing complexity of today's data environments and meet the critical demand for AI-enabled, real-time analytical capabilities.

 

Customer Needs Driving the Transition

Organizations face several critical challenges that SAP BDC is designed to address:
Data Accessibility and Context: Companies struggle with extracting data from SAP systems while maintaining business semantics and context. When data is moved to external platforms, valuable business meaning is often lost, requiring significant time and resources to rebuild .

AI and Analytics Acceleration: Modern businesses need high-quality, AI-ready data to drive reliable and accurate artificial intelligence applications. The traditional approach of fragmented data silos impedes innovation and limits the potential for advanced analytics .

Simplified Data Landscape: Multiple tools, manual processes, and inconsistent data preparation tasks slow the development of advanced analytics and AI capabilities. Organizations seek a unified platform that can eliminate these inefficiencies.

Real-time Insights: The demand for faster time-to-insights requires modern infrastructure capable of supporting real-time decision-making processes across all business functions.

 

Adoption Journey and Transition Approaches
SAP has defined a structured approach to BDC adoption that allows organizations to progress at their own pace while preserving existing investments. The transition follows a three-phase methodology: Lift, Shift, and Innovate.

 

Evolving Beyond SAP Data and Analytics Portfolio

SAP customers utilizing systems like SAP BW (Business Warehouse), SAP HANA, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud are increasingly seeking pathways to modernize their data environments. The introduction of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) represents a major shift, offering organizations an integrated, cloud-native platform capable of unifying data from SAP and non-SAP sources, enabling advanced analytics, and powering AI-driven insights in real time.

Migrating from SAP BW and SAP HANA
Many enterprises have long relied on SAP BW for critical reporting and data warehousing needs. However, with SAP BW 7.5 reaching end of mainstream maintenance in 2027, businesses are tasked with deciding between maintaining aging systems or embracing cloud-ready solutions. BDC allows organizations to lift and shift their existing BW environments—including critical data models and business logic—directly into the cloud, often through SAP BW/4HANA private cloud edition. This preserves past investments while immediately unlocking scalable data products, improved governance, and seamless integration with SAP Datasphere and Databricks for analytics and AI scenarios. SAP HANA customers similarly benefit from BDC’s cloud-native architecture, which supports both structured and unstructured data, and offers scalable compute and flexible storage options for modern workloads.
 

 

Transitioning from SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud
With SAP BDC, customers currently operating SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud can expect a smooth, phased transition. BDC unifies these solutions into a single environment, streamlining workflows and reducing silos. Organizations leverage their existing data pipelines and analytics use cases - with features like zero-copy integration and data product generators - while quickly gaining access to enhanced AI, collaboration tools, and cross-platform interoperability. This means existing assets and semantic models in SAP Datasphere or Analytics Cloud can be retained and enriched rather than rebuilt, simplifying governance and accelerating time to value.
 
 
Key Benefits and Approach
The move to SAP Business Data Cloud is designed to minimize disruption. SAP provides a structured, stepwise migration methodology focused on:
  • Data Continuity: Preserving historical data and business rule integrity.
  • Operational Stability: Supporting parallel operations and robust fallback options during migration.
  • Capability Development: Offering training and resources so teams can maximize the value of BDC features.
  • Unified Data Governance: Centralizing oversight and compliance across all SAP and external data sources.

 

Strategic Planning Resources

It provides clear, concise answers to the most common technical and strategic questions architects encounter, such as how BDC unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, supports semantic modeling, and aligns with existing SAP environments like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP BW.

It provides a centralized platform where architects can explore missions, reference architectures, and best practice guides tailored to the unique challenges of data platform modernization. Through curated use cases and real-world implementation patterns, the Discovery Center clarifies how SAP BDC unifies SAP and non-SAP data, streamlines data integration, and supports advanced analytics and AI. Architects can leverage solution diagrams, architecture blueprints, and tools in the Discovery Center to design resilient, scalable BDC environments.

The SAP Architecture Centre is a strategic hub for enterprise architects navigating the transition to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). It offers in-depth reference architectures, solution diagrams, and best practice guides specifically designed to address the complex requirements of modern data management and cloud adoption.

 

Implementation Support

The Accelerator Hub offers immediate access to an extensive library of ready-to-use integration components, APIs, and architectural templates that simplify the creation and deployment of cloud data solutions designed for SAP's dynamic platform ecosystem. This centralized resource enables architects to rapidly identify, assess, and test APIs along with Data Product and Data Package elements specifically for S/4HANA Private Cloud environments, significantly reducing the challenges commonly encountered during cloud migration and hybrid integration projects.
 

 

The SAP Roadmap Explorer is a powerful tool that helps enterprise architects plan their transition to SAP Business Data Cloud with greater clarity and confidence. It provides a clear view of current features and future innovations related to BDC, allowing architects to understand what’s available now and what’s coming soon. This helps them align technical plans with business goals and make informed decisions about timing, dependencies, and integration points. Overall, the SAP Roadmap Explorer gives architects the insight they need to design a well-structured, future-ready path to SAP Business Data Cloud.

 

Technology Capability Model in LeanIX

 

LeanIX’s Technology Capability Model (TCM) provides a framework for:
  • Current state assessment of existing technology landscapes
  • Target architecture design for future state planning
  • Transformation roadmap development with clear milestones and dependencies
  • Governance structure establishment for implementation oversight

 

Next Steps and Way Forward
Immediate Actions
1. Assess current SAP BW environment using SAP’s free assessment service (SAP Migration Assessment)
2. Evaluate transition readiness through the BDC Discovery Workshop
3. Develop stakeholder alignment across business and IT teams
Medium-term Planning
1. Design target architecture using LeanIX and SAP Architecture Center resources
2. Create detailed migration roadmap with phased approach
3. Establish governance framework for ongoing transformation management
Long-term Vision
1. Implement AI/ML capabilities through Databricks integration
2. Adopt Intelligent Applications for accelerated business value
3. Optimize data product economy for reusable, scalable data assets

The transition to SAP Business Data Cloud represents more than a technical migration - it’s a strategic transformation that positions organizations for the AI-driven future of business. With SAP’s structured approach of Land, Expand, and Adopt, organizations can preserve existing investments while gaining access to cutting-edge capabilities. The comprehensive ecosystem of resources, tools, and professional services ensures that organizations have the support needed to navigate this critical transformation successfully.
With proper planning, stakeholder alignment, and strategic execution, the move to SAP Business Data Cloud can unlock significant business value and competitive advantage in an increasingly data-driven marketplace.

entry.title: Purchase Pilot でフリーテキスト発注を AI 変革 — SAP BTP Hackathon 2025 成果レポート
entry.content:
2025 年春、SAP ジャパン の有志メンバーで結成したチーム 「TO BEs」 は、SAP BTP Hackathon 2025 に参加し、 本ハッカソンの公式テーマ「SAP業務にAIでSurpriseを！それ、AIに任せません？」のもと、社内で“もし自分たちが現場でソリューションを構築するとしたら？”というエキシビションとして挑戦しました。

本記事は、その成果として開発した Purchase Pilot の概要と技術アーキテクチャ、およびデモをまとめたレポートです。SAP Community の皆さんからのフィードバックを楽しみにしています！

 

背景 — フリーテキスト発注が生む 3 つの課題

SAP S/4HANA などの購買業務では、品目マスタが存在しない場合に「テキスト発注」が使われます。しかしこの運用には、以下のような問題がつきまといます。

  1. 業務負荷の増大 — 項目を 1 行ずつ入力・確認する手間。
  2. データ品質の低下 — 記述ゆれや入力ミスで KPI が組めない。
  3. 意思決定の遅延 — 精度の低い実績データが経営判断を鈍らせる。

私たちは、この “曖昧で非定型” な領域こそ AI が真価を発揮する余地だと考えました。

 

ソリューション — Purchase Pilot とは？

迷わず・ミスなく・効率的に。

Purchase Pilot は、現場担当者がテキスト発注を入力する際に AI がリアルタイムで支援 するツールです。コア機能は次の 2 つです。

 

仕組み — 2 つのコア機能を深掘り

1. インテリジェントな入力補完 — 処理フロー

ざっくり 3 ステップで完結します。

  1. 過去レコードをベクトルとして準備
    - 過去の正確なテキスト発注レコードを抽出し、Short Text をベクトル化して Vector Engine へ保存。
  2. 類似レコード × Few‑shot
    - マニュアル入力された Short Text をベクトル化し、類似度検索でトップ 3 件を取得。
  3. 意味情報を加えて補完
    - S/4HANA Cloud からコストセンタ名など “意味テキスト” を取得。
    - LLM が Few‑shot とフィールド定義情報を基に各必要項目を推定し、UI 上で提案。

Few‑shot とは、過去レコードを "お手本" として数件渡すことで、LLM により正確な出力を促す手法です。

 

2. リアルタイムな異常検知 — 処理フロー

流れは次の 4 ステップです。

  1. 過去レコードをベクトルとして準備
    - 過去の正確なテキスト発注レコードを抽出し、Short Text をベクトル化して Vector Engine へ保存。
  2. 品目グループ・発注単位を推定
    - マニュアル入力された Short Text をベクトル化し、類似度検索でトップ 3 件を取得。
    - Few‑shot とフィールド定義情報を組み合わせて、LLM が品目グループと発注単位を推定。
  3. レンジを計算
    - 推定した品目グループをキーに S/4HANA Cloud へ問い合わせ、過去レコードから単価・個数レンジを動的に算出。
  4. 異常を判定 & 警告
    - 入力された単価・個数がレンジ外なら即警告。ユーザーは確認モーダル経由で上書き確定も可能。

 

ソリューションアーキテクチャ

* 印はハッカソン時点では未実装のコンポーネントです。

アーキテクチャ図のポイント

  • SAP BTP Cloud Foundry 上に CAP アプリ (Node.js/Python) を配置し、SAP HANA Cloud と SAP AI Core/Gen AI Hub をサービスブローカー経由で統合。
  • Embedding 処理でテキストをベクトル化し、HANA Cloud の Vector Engine に保存・検索。
  • フロントエンドは SAP Build Work Zone にデプロイされた Fiori Elements アプリとして提供。
  • オンプレ SAP S/4HANA とは Cloud Connector で安全にトンネリングし、購買伝票やマスタを連携。（*は PoC では未接続）
  • SAP Cloud Solutions（S/4HANA Cloud, Ariba など）とも同じ OData/SAP BTP 接続モデルで拡張可能。

 

デモ動画 — “5 分入力” が “数十秒” に短縮

動画の流れ

  1. SAP GUI で従来のフリーテキスト発注
    -  マニュアルでのテキスト発注入力は、操作に慣れたユーザでも約 5 分ほどの時間を要し、いくつかの入力ミスが発生します。
  2. Purchase Pilot - 自動補完機能の実演
    - Recommend ボタンをクリックすると、テキストから勘定コード・単位・コストセンタなどを自動補完します。
  3. Purchase Pilot - 異常検知機能の実演
    - 手入力した伝票に対して Validate ボタンを押すと、AI が不足項目や異常値を即時指摘し、修正アドバイスを提示します。

このソリューションにより、入力時間の削減 や 入力ミスの軽減 を実現することができます！また、異常をリアルタイム検知することで、手戻りがゼロ になり、クリーンなデータによる経営指標を高速更新に繋がります！

 

まとめ

  • SAP ジャパン チーム TO BEs の挑戦: 社員視点で “現場 DX” をテーマに、AI × BTP の可能性を検証
  • Purchase Pilot の価値: テキスト発注という "最後の手入力領域" を AI で変革し、操作性とデータ品質を同時に向上。

ご意見をお聞かせください！ コメント欄や SNS でのフィードバックをお待ちしています。

entry.title: How to fix npm error notarget @sap/hdi-deploy when you create a CAP app in BAS
entry.content:
Update (July 2025): Good news — @sap/hdi-deploy@5.5.0 is now available on npm, so this specific error may have disappeared.
But keep reading! The root cause — a dependency pointing to a version that isn’t published yet—can happen again with future releases. The steps below show how to unblock yourself whenever npm throws a notarget error for an @sap/hdi-deploy package.

 

When do you see this error?

1. In SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) click File → New Project from Template.

2. Choose CAP Project and fill in the project name, runtime (Node.js), database (HANA Cloud), etc.

3. Open the terminal and run:

cds add mta   # create files for Cloud Foundry / Kyma deploy
npm i         # install dependencies​

4. npm i stops with this message:

npm error code ETARGET
npm error notarget No matching version found for @sap/hdi-deploy@5.5.0.​

Even if you force "@SAP/hdi-deploy": "5.4.2" in package.json, the error still appears.

 

Why does it happen?

cds add mta adds this line to devDependencies:

"@sap/cds-dk": ">=8"

@SAP/cds-dk version 8.x asks for @SAP/hdi-deploy@5.5.0, but 5.5.0 is not yet published on npm. So npm cannot find it and throws ETARGET.

 

The 3‑line fix

1.  (Optional) clean old modules and cache:

rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm cache clean --force

2. Install the latest cds-dk (today it is 9.1.3):

npm install -D @sap/cds-dk@latest

3. Install the rest:

npm install

cds-dk 9.x points to @sap/hdi-deploy 5.4.2, which exists, so the install succeeds.

 

Example package.json

{
  "scripts": {
    "start": "cds run"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@sap/cds": "^7",
    "@sap/hana-client": "^2",
    "@sap/xssec": "^3"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@sap/cds-dk": "^9.1.3"
  }
}

 

More Information

SAP Community Q&A (same issue): https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/generate-cap-project-in-bas-with-error-sap-hdi-deploy-5-4-2-not-match/qaq-p/14062673

 

Wrap‑up

Next time you hit the @sap/hdi-deploy notarget error, just remember: upgrade @sap/cds-dk and you are done.

If this post helped you, please give Kudos and leave a comment! 🙌

entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, that’s all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAP’s commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.

entry.title: Anna Hartmann
entry.content:
Anna

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Anna on LinkedIn

Anna is managing director at in4MD Service GmbH. Her journey began with mastering ABAP programming from 2010 to 2013. By 2013, Anna was deeply involved in the HANA environment, managing around 100 databases and developing teaching materials covering areas such as Predictive Analysis Library, Geospatial, Text Mining, Fiori development on HANA, and Smart Data Integration for the SAP University Alliance Program in the SAP University Competence Center Magdeburg. This extensive engagement has equipped her with an in-depth knowledge of the entire HANA platform, both 1.0 and 2.0. Anna is also one of the authors of the SAP Press book "SAP HANA – Datenbankadministration" (ISBN 978-3-8362-6850-9).

Topics of interest: HANA database, HANA Cloud, SAP landscape and architecture, ABAP, BTP

Anna, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

What drives Anna is ensuring the needs of mid-sized customers are met, as they often feel overlooked by SAP. Anna is passionate about being their voice, representing their interests whether through on-premise solutions, cloud (Azure, Google), or RISE and GROW projects. Her diverse background and commitment to these clients makes her an ideal candidate for the SAP Mentor Program, where I can advocate effectively for this crucial segment of the SAP community. Anna also has a broad network within the technical SAP community thanks to the many years of involvement in DSAG.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Get involved into the SAP community, it's a great opportunity to learn from others and gain different perspectives. Stay curious and continuously learn about new SAP technologies and best practices. Network actively with other SAP professionals to share insights and solve challenges together. Always keep the core business processes of your company or customer in mind to deliver real value with your technical solutions.

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, it’s time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Streamlining REST API Integrations in SAP Datasphere with Task Chains and FastAPI on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction 

With the recent introduction of API Tasks in Task Chains, SAP Datasphere now supports direct orchestration of external REST services (see SAP documentation). This enhancement unlocks new integration possibilities, particularly for scenarios where no standard connectors are available. 

In our use case, we aim to extract data from an open REST API and load it into SAP Datasphere. To achieve this, we developed a custom wrapper API—built with FastAPI and hosted on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)—that handles both data extraction and the writing of that data into SAP HANA Cloud, which underlies SAP Datasphere. The entire data loading process is then triggered and managed via a REST API step within a Task Chain. 

At the core of this solution is a lightweight microservice that seamlessly integrates a third-party REST API into SAP Datasphere. The microservice is designed to be modular, secure, and easy to maintain, and enables a fully automated integration pipeline. 

Key Features of the Approach 

  • REST API extraction wrapped in a FastAPI-based microservice 
  • Basic HTTP Authentication for secure access 
  • Data retrieval from public or external REST APIs 
  • Automatic detection and mapping of SAP HANA-compatible data types 
  • Dynamic table creation in SAP HANA Cloud 
  • Batch data insertion with upload timestamps for traceability 
  • Deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) 
  • Registration as an HTTP connection in SAP Datasphere 
  • Integration into a Task Chain for full orchestration of the data workflow 

 

 

Requirement 

Data integration from 3rd-party REST APIs is still a challenge in SAP Datasphere, particularly when no standard connectors are available. SAP offers solutions like Open Connectors or SAP Cloud Integration via the Integration Suite. However, these options come with additional cost and infrastructure overhead. 

Our proposed solution is a lightweight, developer-friendly alternative that utilizes: 

  • A simple REST service hosted on SAP BTP 
  • Open SQL schema access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud instance 
  • Integration into Task Chains via the new REST API task type 

This allows full orchestration and governance from within SAP Datasphere, without introducing unnecessary middleware layers. 

Solution 

FastAPI Solution on SAP BTP 

At the core of this architecture lies a microservice built with FastAPI. This Python-based service acts as a universal adapter to extract, transform (lightly), and load data into SAP HANA Cloud. The code can also be found in our GIT repository. 

Key Components 

  1. Authentication 
    All secure endpoints require HTTP Basic Authentication, with credentials configurable via environment variables. 
  2. HANA Integration 
    1. Using the hana_ml library, the service connects to the HANA Cloud database and  
      automatically detects column types using heuristics (e.g., timestamp recognition, length-adjusted NVARCHAR) 
    2. Dynamically creates a table if it doesn't exist 
    3. Inserts records in batch mode, with an added UPLOAD_TS timestamp column 

  3. Endpoints

    Endpoint 

    Method 

    Description 

    / 

    GET 

    Health check 

    /test-hana-connection 

    GET 

    Verifies database credentials and connection 

    /extract-and-write 

    POST 

    Triggers extraction from a third-party API and writes to HANA 

    /preview-data 

    GET 

    Fetches sample records from a REST API 

    /infer-types 

    GET 

    Infers HANA-compatible types from JSON response 

  4. Deployment 
    The service is packaged with a manifest.yaml for deployment on SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry). It uses the Python buildpack and runs via uvicorn in production. 
     

Outlook 

This FastAPI-based solution can be flexibly extended to support more advanced integration needs: 

  • Authentication: Easily add OAuth2, API keys, or Bearer tokens to handle secured APIs. 
  • REST Call Chaining: Implement multi-step workflows by chaining dependent API calls asynchronously. 
  • Pagination: Add logic for offset, cursor, or token-based pagination to collect full datasets. 
  • Schema Flexibility: Support field renaming, normalization of nested JSON, and custom type overrides. 

Testing 

For Testing purposes we tested everything with Postman and the public available Harry Potter API https://hp-api.onrender.com. 

SAP Datasphere Integration 

To communicate with this BTP service we performed the following steps: 

  1. Whitelist the IPs of our BTP instance in the SAP Datasphere tenant (For testing from Business Application Studio (BAS)you may also want to whitelist those IPs as well) 
  2. Create a HTTP connection for the usage in the Task Chain 

     

     

In the task chain we can now add this step and configure the body. 

 

 

In the Configuration panel we can now select our HTTP connection: 

 

 

And also configure our REST call: 

After running the Task Chain we can see the data is now loaded into our table. 

 

Conclusion 

The integration of a FastAPI-based microservice into SAP Datasphere via Task Chains marks a significant advancement in streamlining data ingestion from third-party REST APIs. By leveraging SAP BTP for deployment and utilizing the new REST API task type within Task Chains, we demonstrated a lightweight and developer-friendly alternative to traditional integration tools like SAP Cloud Integration or Open Connectors. 

Looking ahead, the framework can be extended to accommodate more complex data workflows, robust security models, and advanced transformation logic. With this foundation, organizations can seamlessly orchestrate external data services within SAP Datasphere while maintaining full control, traceability, and governance—all without the need for additional middleware.

entry.title: Why an organisation should always strive to keep a clean core in all transformation projects
entry.content:
What is a transformation Journey and why would a business choose to begin one?

There are many issues faced by businesses today in the ever-continuing goal to become ‘best run’. Some of these issues include natural disasters, geopolitical tensions such as tariffs, wars and other events that previously were once in a lifetime events, these are now the new common challenges of businesses in the modern age. Any one of these challenges or multiple of them combined can prompt a business to embark on a transformation journey.

An Enterprise small or big who wishes to unlock the full potential of their business in any sort of business landscape must leverage information technology as an important tooling. In a partnership with SAP, this enterprise can employ a guided transformation journey such as RISE with SAP. A transformation journey can be intimidating but with guided transformation journeys like RISE, the process can be simplified. [1]

Some motivations for the transformation could include:

  1. The Increasing Disruption of Global Supply Chains:
    Global supply chains are increasingly vulnerable to disruptions that highlight the critical need for resilience, agility, and the ability to adapt quickly. Events such as the EverGiven ship blockage in the Suez Canal illustrate how a single incident can unravel an entire organization crippling production schedules, depleting inventory levels, and significantly impacting customer satisfaction.
  2. Challenges in Meeting Evolving Customer Expectations:
    Modern businesses face a paradigm shift in managing customer expectations. The era of simple B2C (business-to-consumer) engagements has evolved into consumers demanding personalized solutions tailored to their specific needs. Additionally, customers expect businesses to prioritize sustainability and adhere to ethical practices, requiring organizations to be agile and responsive to changing societal demands. it is not enough for a business to simply sell shoes or clothes anymore. They need to ensure ethical sourcing and reduced carbon footprint for there entire chain of business.
  3. The Pressure to Keep Pace with Technological Advancements:
    Rapid technological advancements are transforming industries across the globe. Businesses must embrace innovation to stay competitive. whether that involves adopting AI-driven insights, enabling real-time data analysis, or leveraging automation to streamline operations. Falling behind in technology adoption not only puts companies at a disadvantage but can also limit their ability to innovate and scale efficiently.
  1. Some additional motivations for customers who undergo a transformation journey such as rise with sap could include the need for real time insights into their business, increasing the robustness and responsiveness of their systems, increased cloud flexibility and ability to maneuver operations to take advantage of new opportunities or to avoid potential downfalls.

Due to these challenges and new business opportunities a business might decide to embark on a transformation journey; from an old ERP System to a newer one in efforts to take advantage of the benefits of the cloud such as increased agility and ability to scale. [2] New modern comprehensive packages like S4HANA Cloud can provide this.  In this transformation journey, an important choice must be made. The choice is whether to opt for a brand-new implementation (greenfield) or a system conversion (“brownfield”) implementation strategy. [3] The challenges in keeping the core clean in these two implementation strategies are different.  [4]

While these benefits can be realized from a transformation process, they can be undermined by the negative effects that may arise if the customer fails to prioritize maintaining a clean core. Keeping the core processes clean and free of irrelevant customizations reduces technical debt, improved business adaptability and enables more agile businesses are key principles that define the importance of clean core. [5]

 

What is the clean core strategy and why is it necessary?

From the dawn of Enterprise Resource Planning “Keeping the core clean” has always been a goal. Although most businesses might believe they are completely different in terms of business structure or complexity, enterprise resource planning [6]

Clean core simply represents the ERP system without any baggage such as layers and layers of custom code, it means keeping your ERP System close to SAP Defined standard as much as possible while handling the integrations of extensions and modifications through SAP Defined best practices.  [5]. Clean means Up to date, transparent, unmodified, consistent, efficient and cloud compliant, Core means the main aspects of an ERP system landscape, the extensibility, data, integration and processes. [7]

Following a clean core strategy includes the active efforts to reduce data and process inconsistencies, establish suitable housekeeping processes and governance structures, maximizing the use of SAP’s standard functionality and minimizing the complexity of customization [7]

 

SAP’S Clean Core Approach.

A business operating at its optimal core will have an up-to-date system with cloud-compliant extensions and seamless integration. SAP for a long time has offered extensive capabilities for its software to be extended primarily through ABAP. Businesses were able to tailor the software to their specific market needs. However this freedom to customize however lead to significant long-term challenges that were expensive both financially and in terms of time. Customers who frequently customize functionality to align with a specific process result in the creation of thousands of custom objects, often lacking proper governance and documentation.

This technical debt can result in security vulnerabilities, degraded performance, and widespread system instability, making upgrades and transformations costly, complex, and time-consuming, effectively trapping companies in outdated software. Clean core emerged as a response to these challenges, addressing past architectural limitations by shifting from “in-core” ABAP customization to low-code, no-code, pro-code, and side-by-side solutions available on SAP BTP. [9]

 

 

Clean Core and its benefits during and after a transformation project.

There are multiple approaches to applying a clean core transformation; In a greenfield scenario, we can start from fresh and adopt a clean core from the beginning. This approach enables us to get all the key benefits of clean core right out of the box. On the contrary, however, a brownfield approach allows the new instance to maintain some of the old instance’s complexities and possibly unwanted customizations. In this scenario we must embark on a journey to get the core to become clean.  

Businesses may adopt a brownfield approach when existing processes are too complex or costly to restart, opting instead to preserve core operations. Yet even in these cases, maintaining a clean core is critical. A CTO evaluating the effort will inevitably ask: what is in it for us with clean core?

Keeping a clean core at heart implies a minimization of the need for custom code. Which directly translates into lower maintenance cost. This approach will reduce the total cost of ownership due to reducing maintenance. Also, technical debt which is the accrued cost of past fixes and nonstandard implementations, will also be a significant drain on the budget of an IT department saddled with an unclean core after a brownfield project is complete. [8]  

By working towards a clean core, organizations might begin to see a reduction in the total cost of ownership of the software and the ability to deploy its resources towards newer business issues rather than trying to solve the problem that comes from an accrual of technical debt. Keeping to the clean core emphasis on standard functionality helps in the development of a more robust and predictable system which directly enhances user productivity and satisfaction.

Keeping a clean core can enable more swifter updates. Some firms have reported cutting upgrade timelines by as much as 40%., traditionally as any large business who has implemented an ERP Solution will tell you upgrades are slow, and extremely expensive. Clean core changes this dynamic by decoupling custom logic which enables businesses to consume SAP’s Innovation rapidly. [8]

Having a clean core could also leave a business better equipped to handle various regulation and security standards. A clean core environment is easier to monitor as there are now clearer boundaries between the core ERP System. Reduced complexity will also lead to a higher level of security as fewer entry points are now present within the system. [8]

To support the clean core journey SAP, a strong advocate of maintaining a clean core both during and after a transformation provide instruments to enable the achievement and sustenance of clean core. In a clean core architected environment as recommended, the architectural approach as provided by sap supports the extension of features through well-defined public APIs, Business events which is a system generated notification in the ERP that something has occurred eg: a purchase order has been approved, or a goods movement has been posted.  [4]

External applications can subscribe to the event and trigger processes or workflows. This new approach by SAP removes the need for modifying the core of the software allowing for loose coupling. It enables businesses to react to change in real time without the need to modify the ERP of the software.

This approach means it is now easier to swap out, update or add new functionality with minimal disruption enabling the workforce to take advantage at any key moment of the new benefits offered by the cloud environment after a transformation project to S4HANA.

Beyond technical best practices the SAP clean core strategy of enabling teams to extend the system alongside the core rather than modifying it directly provides more room to build, test, and iterate without compromising stability. For example, one SAP customer experienced a four-month delay during a scheduled rollout due to dependencies tied to their legacy Z-code. Such delays can be costly in time, money, and momentum. By reducing reliance on core modifications, clean core emphasizes modular development, where individual components contribute to overall system agility.

Achieving and Sustaining Clean Core after the transformation project

 

 

The main goals to maintain clean core after the transformation.

Since our organizational goal is to achieve and maintain a clean core, it is essential to define the key components and indicators of a clean core, as well as the practices required to preserve it.

  1. Clean Extensions
  2. Clean Business Processes
  3. Clean Data

Clean Extensions: After the transformation journey is completed, a business need or requirement might provide a situation in which the business needs to add extensions to their ERP Systems. Extensions could help to meet various needs while providing immense value; but in order not to ruin the efforts we have undertaken so far to keep the core clean; it is important that we ensure they are implemented in a clean core compliant manner.

S4HANA is feature-rich, so organizations should critically assess the need for extensions before creating them, as the required functionality may already be available through SAP BTP. Extensions must be designed to support seamless ERP upgrades, avoiding risks or disruptions. Development teams should fully understand the requirements before starting and determine whether an extension should be implemented on-stack or side-by-side. Classical extension techniques are strongly discouraged, as they increase the likelihood of system instability, upgrade failures, and higher maintenance costs.

If, after evaluating all features, a business still requires extensions to meet its objectives, they should be implemented either internally within S4HANA Cloud as on-stack extensions or externally as side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP. SAP’s ABAP Cloud Development Model (CDM) enforces the use of released APIs and applies syntax checks to ensure compliance.

Keeping extensions clean is essential because poorly designed or non-compliant extensions can cause upgrade delays, break business-critical processes, introduce security vulnerabilities, and significantly increase long-term maintenance overhead. By minimizing unnecessary extensions, ensuring compliance with cloud standards, and aligning with customer requirements, organizations can maximize ERP effectiveness while maintaining a clean core.

 

Diagram of clean core extensibility with BTP.

Clean Business Processes: Organizations aiming to maintain a clean core must establish a strong organizational structure with clearly defined roles and responsibilities. This structure, combined with the selection of scalable, secure technological tools, forms the foundation for maintaining clean processes. During and after the transformation, tools such as Signavio Process Manager and Signavio Process Governance enhance process visibility, improve internal compliance, and accelerate business process optimization. [11]

By leveraging these solutions within a clean core environment, businesses can better understand their processes, identify root causes of issues more easily, and reduce both transformation time and risk outcomes that are far harder to achieve without a clean process core. Well-documented, efficient processes also help organizations remain competitive in a fast-paced business environment, ultimately leading to stronger results.

Clean Data: In the cloud and digital age, clean, usable data is one of the most valuable assets for organizations, enabling faster decision-making and actionable insights. Following a transformation to S4HANA Cloud, businesses gain a robust platform for managing, processing, and applying data effectively.

However, data is only as valuable as the processes and principles that ensure its cleanliness. The three main pillars of clean data are:

  • Accuracy: Data must reflect the true state of the business. Without proper validation rules, regular quality checks, and governance, inaccurate data can lead to faulty decisions, inefficient processes, and reduced user trust. Regular audits and automated checks help prevent these issues.
  • Completeness: Incomplete data undermines decision-making and trust. Businesses should enforce standardized data entry, validation processes, and comprehensive collection practices to maintain completeness.
  • Consistency: Data must be uniform across systems. Inconsistencies create confusion, errors, and inefficiencies. Maintaining standards, conducting profiling, and implementing integration and reconciliation processes are critical to consistency. [4]

Maintaining a clean core with respect to data maximizes the value derived from data, enhances process efficiency, and reduces total cost of ownership by enabling efficient management of data volumes and reliable results from business processes.

Conclusion

Regardless of the motivations for a transformation journey, maintaining a clean core during and after the process delivers significant organizational value. Beyond reducing total cost of ownership, a clean core enables the adoption of the latest innovations a critical advantage in the AI-driven era and provides the flexibility to meet evolving business objectives.

The five pillars of clean core represent more than a technological change; they signify a mindset and paradigm shift from on-premise to cloud-based systems. This shift affects custom code, data, processes, and overall business operations, keeping them effective and efficient.

When combined with a transformation initiative, a clean core unlocks a new operational paradigm, maximizing business potential and supporting the development of a sustainable, best-run enterprise. Given these combined benefits, it is clear that maintaining a clean core during a transformation journey is in the best interest of any organization.

Find the Github for this project here

Introduction: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is the ability to process written language like English or other languages and convert it into a format that computers can understand. SQL (Structured Query Language) is a language used to manage and manipulate data within a database system.

SQL has a limited set of operations, making it syntactically simple and easy to learn. This also makes it easier for large language models to generate accurate SQL queries, unlike programming languages like Java, which offer many ways to accomplish the same task.

Natural Language to SQL (NL2SQL) provides an interface that allows non-technical users to interact with databases, explore data, and gather insights without prior SQL knowledge. While a basic understanding of SQL is not required, it is beneficial, as it helps users phrase queries more accurately and obtain better results from the system.

Users who rarely interact with databases no longer need to manually write complex queries. They can simply communicate with the bot and receive accurate responses. Implementing an NL2SQL system saves time and provides a faster, more efficient way to generate real business insights.

Prerequisites for Building This:

  • A working Python environment
  • HANA Cloud
  • AI Core on BTP
  • A dataset to query (for this example, the Spotify listening history dataset from Kaggle)
  • Streamlit to create a chat-style interface for querying the database

My Dataset

 

These are the descriptions of some of the data contained in my dataset. you can find the dataset here, however compared to a real world database; this database is simple and does not have any of the following complications that make a NL2SQL implementation difficult.

  • In a real world scenario the same data can be formatted in many different ways. Sex can be represented as Male, male or M. Different locations have different ways of representing digits eg: 1,000 vs 1.000.
  • If the LLM Lack the domain specific understanding it could misunderstand the user queries.
  • SQL IS Strict with its syntax like every other programming language. if the generated code does not match its strict syntax rules it will fail.
  • Questions can be ambigous and this is why a standard knowledge of SQL is ideal to make this solution work. a simple question about ‘Who is the most popular artist’ can elicit responses such as total minutes played, or who was skipped the least etc.

To address these challenges, we can implement a prompt engineering approach where questions are classified by complexity. More complex questions are checked for ambiguity, and vector embeddings are used to generate accurate and reliable responses.

When a user asks a question, we collect high-quality question/SQL pairs and store them in HANA. The more the system is used, the better it becomes at generating SQL statements. For new questions, vector embeddings are created and searched against the database of existing solutions to find the most relevant response.

But for now this is a basic implementation of the system.

The first step is to create a database schema. this just shows the initial relationship between the tables, how the data can be stored and the columns.
I created this table and my schema in my HANA database as follows, hanas columnar based storage might make it differ from yours if you use another database.

artist_name NVARCHAR(255),
album_name NVARCHAR(255),
reason_start NVARCHAR(100),
reason_end NVARCHAR(100),
shuffle BOOLEAN,

);

I then uploaded my data to hana. Usually a large data source like this wont be manually uploaded but would be gathered from many places into one centralized location to be queried.

 

Importing initial components

Pandas is a library used for working with datasets, HDBCLI is the python interface for working with the HANA Cloud Database.

entry.title: 🚀☁️ Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud: A Business Transformation Journey
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

📝Introduction

In today’s fast-paced business environment, enterprises are under constant pressure to reduce costs 💰, accelerate innovation 🚀, and stay agile ⚡. Many organizations still run on-premise SAP HANA 🗄️ or ECC systems 🏢, which can limit scalability, slow analytics 📊, and increase IT overhead 🛠️.

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud ☁️ offers a solution: a cloud-native, scalable, and intelligent platform 🤖 that not only modernizes your database but also unlocks new opportunities for business growth 📈, advanced analytics 📊, and AI-driven insights 🤖.

This blog explores the strategic advantages of moving to HANA Cloud, real-world scenarios, migration approaches, and how businesses can leverage this transformation for long-term success 🌟.

1. Why Businesses Should Care About Migration

SAP HANA on-premise has been the backbone of enterprise IT for over a decade. But today, companies face challenges like:

  • 💸Rising infrastructure and data center costs

  • 📉Difficulty scaling for seasonal or global demand

  • ⚡Pressure to innovate with real-time analytics and machine learning

SAP HANA Cloud is not just a database upgrade — it is a strategic enabler for business transformation:

  • ☁️Elastic scalability → pay only for what you use

  • 💰Lower TCO → no hardware refresh, no patching overhead

  • 🤖Built-in innovation → multi-model (graph, JSON, geospatial), ML integration, Datasphere

  • 🛡️ Cloud-grade resilience → HA, backups, encryption built in

👉For enterprises planning RISE with SAP, migration is often a key milestone. For GROW with SAP customers, HANA Cloud is already the default foundation.

2. A Real-World Story: Fashion Retailer Migrating During Peak Season

A large fashion retailer running ECC on HANA on-premise faced challenges during peak shopping seasons:

  • 🏬High traffic spikes during Black Friday, festive sales, and seasonal launches

  • 💾Hardware was over-provisioned to handle peak loads but under-utilized the rest of the year

  • 📊Analytics delays slowed decision-making for inventory replenishment, pricing, and promotions

By migrating to SAP HANA Cloud, the retailer was able to:

  • ☁️Scale compute resources elastically during high-demand weeks, then scale down during off-season

  • 📊Integrate sales, inventory, and supply chain data in SAP Datasphere for real-time visibility

  • 💰Reduce infrastructure costs by 25–30% while improving system performance

  • 🛒Optimize promotional planning and inventory allocation by leveraging faster analytics on HANA Cloud

👉Result: Smooth operations during peak shopping periods, lower costs, faster reporting, and improved customer satisfaction — all while creating a foundation for a future move to S/4HANA Cloud.

3.🛠️⚡ Migration Approach: Self-Service Tools for a Smooth Transition

Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud can be complex, but SAP provides self-service migration tools to simplify the process, reduce risk, and speed up implementation.

1️⃣Assessment & Planning

  • 🛠️ Review current HANA workloads, database size, and custom code.

  • 📝Decide whether to migrate using sidecar (DB only) or full migration.

  • 🔒Map compliance, security, and network requirements.

  • 📊Identify business processes to migrate first (e.g., analytics sandbox or critical ERP data).

👉Reference: SAP HANA Cloud Migration Guide

2️⃣Execution with SAP Self-Service Migration Tools

SAP HANA Cloud Migration Cockpit / DMO (Database Migration Option):

  • 🛠️ Self-service migration: Provides a guided, wizard-based process for migrating data from on-premise HANA or BTP HANA Service to HANA Cloud.

  • ⚡Supports multiple migration scenarios:

    • ECC on HANA → HANA Cloud (sidecar or full)

    • S/4HANA on-prem → HANA Cloud

    • SAP HANA Service on BTP CF → HANA Cloud

  • 🔄Automated delta replication: Keeps source and target databases in sync until cutover.

  • 🖥️ Validation & monitoring: Allows pre-checks, logs, and real-time monitoring of migration progress.

  • 🔗Seamless integration: Works with SAP tools like SLT/SDI, SUM/DMO, and SAP Cloud Transport.

Key Benefits:

  • Reduces manual steps and risk of errors.

  • Speeds up migration timeline.

  • Provides a self-service experience for IT teams, while still supporting SAP guidance and best practices.

👉Learning resource: SAP Learning Journey – Migrating SAP HANA to HANA Cloud

3️⃣Hands-On Simulation

  • 🖥️ Practice provisioning, configuring, and validating migration steps using SAP’s interactive simulation.

  • 👉Try it here: Enable Now Demo

4. Customer Scenarios: How Migration Helps Different Starting Points

🔹1. Customers on ECC on HANA (on-premise)

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Running legacy ECC (not yet S/4HANA) with an SAP HANA database on-premise

  • 💸Facing high infra + maintenance costs, limited innovation

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️They can move their database layer first (sidecar or full migration) → reduce infra costs immediately

  • 🛠️ This becomes a stepping stone to RISE with SAP (moving ERP to S/4HANA Cloud later is easier if DB is already on HANA Cloud)

  • 📊Can use HANA Cloud for analytics scenarios while still keeping ECC running on-prem

Scenario Architecture:

[💻 Users/Apps]
      |
      v
+-------------------+        Initial Load          +---------------------+
| 🗄️ ECC (ABAP stack)|----------------------------->| ☁️ SAP HANA Cloud   |
+---------^---------+                              +----------^----------+
          |                                                 |
          |   Real-time Delta (SLT/SDI/DP Agent)            |
          +-----------------------------------------------> |
          |                                                 |
+---------+---------+                                       |
| 🗄️ SAP HANA (source)|<----- 🔗 VPN/Private Link/IPSec ---+
+-------------------+

👉Benefit: Lower TCO now, smoother path to S/4HANA in future

🔹2. Customers on S/4HANA On-Premise

Current State:

  • 🗄️ Already on S/4HANA, but hosted in on-premise data center

  • 💸Often invested in large HANA appliances sized for peak loads

How HANA Cloud Helps:

  • ☁️Lift & shift the database layer to HANA Cloud under RISE with SAP

  • ⚡Elastic scaling → no more overprovisioning

  • 📊Cloud-native features like multi-model DB and Datasphere integration unlock new business insights

  • 🛡️ Reduces IT overhead (patching, HA setup, backup) — handled by SAP

Scenario Architecture:
